an10.93:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an10.93:4.2: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika left Sāvatthī in the middle of the day to see the Buddha.
an10.93:4.4: “It’s the wrong time to see the Buddha,
an10.93:4.6: And it’s the wrong time to see the esteemed mendicants,
an10.93:4.8: Why don’t I go to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths?”
an10.93:5.1: Then he went to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths.
an10.93:5.2: Now at that time, the wanderers who follow other paths had come together, making an uproar, a dreadful racket as they sat and talked about all kinds of crude topics.
an10.93:5.3: They saw Anāthapiṇḍika coming off in the distance,
an10.93:5.5: “Be quiet, good sirs, don’t make a sound.
an10.93:5.6: The householder Anāthapiṇḍika, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama, is coming into our monastery.
an10.93:5.7: He is included among the white-clothed lay disciples of the ascetic Gotama, who is residing in Sāvatthī.
an10.93:5.8: Such venerables like the quiet, are educated to be quiet, and praise quiet.
an10.93:5.9: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
an10.93:6.1: Then those wanderers who follow other paths fell silent.
an10.93:6.2: Then Anāthapiṇḍika went up to them,
an10.93:6.3: and exchanged greetings with the wanderers there.
an10.93:6.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
an10.93:6.6: “Tell us, householder, what is the view of the ascetic Gotama?”
an10.93:6.7: “Sirs, I don’t know all his views.”
an10.93:7.1: “Well then, since it seems you don’t know all the views of the ascetic Gotama,
an10.93:7.2: tell us, what is the view of the mendicants?”
an10.93:7.3: “Sirs, I don’t know all the mendicants’ views.”
an10.93:8.1: “Well then, since it seems you don’t know all the views of the ascetic Gotama or of the mendicants,
an10.93:8.2: tell us, householder, what is your view?”
an10.93:8.3: “Sirs, it’s not hard for me to explain what my views are.
an10.93:8.4: But please, let the venerables explain their own convictions first. Afterwards it won’t be hard for me to explain my views.”
an10.93:9.1: When he said this, one of the wanderers said to him:
an10.93:9.2: “The world is eternal. This is the only truth, other ideas are stupid.
an10.93:10.2: “The world is not eternal. This is the only truth, other ideas are stupid.
an10.93:11.4: “The soul and the body are the same thing …” …
an10.93:11.5: “The soul and the body are different things …” …
an10.93:11.7: “A Realized One doesn’t exist after death …” …
an10.93:11.8: “A Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death …” …
an10.93:11.9: “A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, other ideas are stupid.
an10.93:12.1: When this was said, Anāthapiṇḍika said this:
an10.93:12.2: “Sirs, regarding the venerable who said this:
an10.93:12.3: ‘The world is eternal. This is the only truth, other ideas are stupid.
an10.93:12.4: That’s my view, householder.’ This view of his has either arisen from his own irrational reflection, or is conditioned by what someone else said.
an10.93:12.5: But that view is created, conditioned, chosen, dependently originated.
an10.93:12.6: Anything that is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.
an10.93:12.8: What he clings to and holds to is just suffering.
an10.93:13.1: Regarding the venerable who said this:
an10.93:13.2: ‘The world is not eternal. This is the only truth, other ideas are stupid.
an10.93:13.3: That’s my view, householder.’ This view of his has either arisen from his own irrational reflection, or is conditioned by what someone else said.
an10.93:13.4: But that view is created, conditioned, chosen, dependently originated.
an10.93:13.5: Anything that is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.
an10.93:13.7: What he clings to and holds to is just suffering.
an10.93:14.1: Regarding the venerable who said this:
an10.93:14.4: ‘The soul and the body are the same thing …’ …
an10.93:14.5: ‘The soul and the body are different things …’ …
an10.93:14.7: ‘A Realized One doesn’t exist after death …’ …
an10.93:14.8: ‘A Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death …’ …
an10.93:14.9: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, other ideas are stupid.
an10.93:14.10: That’s my view, householder.’ This view of his has either arisen from his own irrational reflection, or is conditioned by what someone else said.
an10.93:14.11: But that view is created, conditioned, chosen, dependently originated.
an10.93:14.12: Anything that is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.
an10.93:14.14: What he clings to and holds to is just suffering.”
an10.93:15.1: When he said this the wanderers said to him:
an10.93:15.2: “Householder, we’ve each explained our own convictions.
an10.93:15.3: Tell us, householder, what is your view?”
an10.93:15.4: “Sirs, anything that is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.
an10.93:15.6: And what’s suffering is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.
an10.93:16.1: “Householder, anything that is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.
an10.93:16.3: What you cling to and hold to is just suffering.”
an10.93:17.1: “Sirs, anything that is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.
an10.93:17.3: And I’ve truly seen clearly with right wisdom that what’s suffering is not mine, I am not this, it’s not my self.
an10.93:17.5: And I truly understand the escape beyond that.”
an10.93:18.1: When this was said, those wanderers sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
an10.93:18.2: Seeing this, Anāthapiṇḍika got up from his seat. He went to the Buddha,
an10.93:18.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
an10.93:18.4: and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.
an10.93:18.6: That’s how you should legitimately and completely refute those foolish men from time to time.”
an10.93:19.1: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired the householder Anāthapiṇḍika with a Dharma talk,
an10.93:19.2: after which Anaāthapiṇḍika got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha before leaving.
an10.93:20.1: Then, not long after Anāthapiṇḍika had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an10.93:20.2: “Mendicants, even a mendicant who has ordained for a hundred years in this teaching and training would legitimately and completely refute those wanderers who follow other paths just as the householder Anāthapiṇḍika did.”
